Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: National retail pharmacy chain Walgreens paid the United States and four participating states $9.9 million to resolve allegations of falsely billing the Medicaid program.

The Walgreens pharmacy chain paid the United States and participating states $7.9 million to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by  offering illegal inducements to beneficiaries of government health care programs, including Medicare, Medicaid, TRICARE and the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program, in the form of gift cards, gift checks and other similar promotions to transfer their prescriptions to Walgreens pharmacies.

National pharmacy chain Walgreens agreed to pay nearly $6 million to settle FTC charges that the company deceptively advertised Wal-Born, a line of dietary supplements similar to the Airborne cold-and-flu treatment,  using the same kind of baseless claims that the supplements could prevent colds, fight germs, and boost the immune system.
Walgreens agreed to pay $80 million to resolve what the DEA called an unprecedented number of record-keeping and dispensing violations under the Controlled Substances Act.
retaliation

Health & Human Services Department Office of Inspector General

Description: Walgreen Co. paid $9.86 million to resolve allegations that it violated the federal False Claims Act when it knowingly submitted claims for reimbursement to California's Medi-Cal program that were not supported by applicable diagnosis and documentation requirements.

The settlement resolved claims that Walgreens violated the federal Anti-Kickback Statute and False Claims Act by enrolling hundreds of thousands of beneficiaries of government healthcare programs in its Prescription Savings Club program with discounts and other monetary incentives, in order to induce them to patronize Walgreen pharmacies for all of their prescription drug needs.
Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York
U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York

Description: Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc. agreed to settle allegations that it misled investors about increased risk that the company would miss a key financial goal announced when Walgreen entered into a merger with Alliance Boots GmbH in 2012.

Walgreen Co. agreed to pay $3.5 million to the United States and the State of Wisconsin to settle allegations that it submitted claims to Medicaid for stimulant medications without complying with Medicaid rules designed to ensure that stimulants are dispensed for appropriate medical treatment.

Walgreens agreed to pay the United States and state governments a total of $269.2 million to resolve allegations that it improperly billed Medicare, Medicaid, and other federal healthcare programs for hundreds of thousands of insulin pens it knowingly dispensed to program beneficiaries who did not need them and that it overbilled Medicaid by failing to disclose to and charge Medicaid the lower drug prices that Walgreens offered the public through a discount program.
Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York

Description: The New York Attorney General announced a settlement with four pharmacy chains requiring them to accept returnable beverage bottles and cans. The pharmacies also agreed to pay a total of $66,000 to the state. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the amount was divided evenly among them.
sale of expired and incorrectly priced products
sale of expired products

Walgreens agreed to pay $16.4 million to settle multistate claims that from 2001 to 2005 it improperly switched patients to different versions of the prescription drugs Ranitidine, Fluoxetine and Eldepryl in order to increase its reimbursement from Medicaid. This was part of a larger $35 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-walgreen-co

Walgreens agreed to pay $3.79 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it  violated anti-kickback and false claims laws by enrolling hundreds of thousands of beneficiaries of government healthcare programs in its Prescription Savings Club program with discounts and other monetary incentives, in order to induce them to patronize Walgreen pharmacies for all of their prescription drug needs. This was part of a larger $50 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-walgreen-co-2
A group of major retailers and a group of jewelry manufacturers joined a settlement involving the presence of lead in costume jewelry sold to children.
The Walgreen Co. agreed to pay $140,000 in settlement of allegations it double-billed for some prescriptions that were eligible for both Medicaid and Medicare.
breach of customers' medical information
Info Source: Attorney General: CVS, Walgreens Agree to New Consumer Protections to Resolve Pharmacy Data-Breach Complaints, Settle Cases, States News Service, July 10, 2009 (via Nexis).

Description: overbilling for prescription drugs

National retail pharmacy chain Walgreens agreed to pay $9.9 million to four states -- Florida, Massachusetts, Michigan and Minnesota -- and the federal government to resolve allegations of falsely billing the Medicaid program with regard to customers that also had private third-party coverage. The settlement was also announced by the Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-walgreens-1

Walgreens agreed to pay approximately $600,00 to settle multistate litigation alleging it offered illegal inducements to beneficiaries of government health care programs to transfer their prescriptions to its pharmacies. This was part of a larger $7.9 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-walgreens-0

Walgreens agreed to make sweeping changes in its operations as part of a settlement of multistate litigation concerning the sale of tobacco products to minors. The company also agreed to pay $320,000 to the states.

The California Attorney General announced a $9.8 million settlement with Walgreens to resolve allegations that it failed to adhere fully to requirements imposed by California law for the dispensing of certain prescriptions drugs under Medi-Cal.
Walgreens agreed to pay $150,000 for an independent monitor and $350,000 to the state in settlement of allegations that many of its drug stores limited access for individuals with disablities.
Walgreens agreed to pay $5.5 million in settlement of allegations it overcharged for prescription drugs covered by the state workers' compensation insurance system.
Walgreens agreed to pay $200,000  as part of a settlement of allegations it failed to monitor drug use patterns or use professional judgment when dispensing controlled substances.
Walgreens agreed to pay $2.8 million in settlement of allegations it overcharged public entities for prescription drugs under the workers' compensation insurance system.
CVS,Walgreens and Wal-Mart agreed to settle allegations they misled consumers in the collection of a $1.30 pharmacy assessment.
Walgreens agreed to pay $185,000 in settlement of allegations it violated waste management regulations related to photo processing materials.
Walgreens agreed to pay $550,000 in settlement of allegations it failed to individually price items as required under Michigan law.
Walgreens was ordered to pay $309,000 after it was judged in violation of a June 2014 settlement by leaving sales tags on shelves after the sales period expired, overcharging customers.

Walgreens Boots Alliance agreed to pay $41.2 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it engaged in fraudulent conduct when it dispensed insulin pens. Walgreens was alleged to have not always adhered to the dosage outlined by the prescribing doctor, but rather dispensed insulin pens in boxes containing five pens, regardless of the patient's needs. This resulted in a pattern where beneficiaries were routinely receiving more insulin than prescribed and Walgreens was then billing Medicaid for the additional doses. At the same time, Walgreens agreed to pay $28 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it overcharged Medicaid by failing to disclose discounts offered to customers. These cases were part of two larger settlements  totaling $269 million involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-walgreens-boots-alliance-inc-0

Walgreens agreed to pay $2,250,000 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Santa Clara, Contra Costa, San Mateo and Santa Cruz counties that is sold expired baby food, infant formula, and over the counter drugs.

Walgreens agreed to pay $502,200 in settlement of allegations its pharmacists did not fully comply with the state Board of Pharmacy's rules requiring a personal consultation when customers received a new or changed prescription. The settlement was with the District Attorneys of of Alameda, Riverside and San Diego counties.

Walgreens agreed to pay $16.57 million in settlement of allegations by 43 California District Attorneys and two City Attorneys that it violated laws over the storage, handling and disposing of hazardous waste when dealing with products used and sold by its stores, as well as failing to correctly dispose of customer records containing confidential medical information.

Walgreens agreed to pay $767,000 to the District Attorneys of San Mateo and Santa Clara counties to resolve allegations that of discrepancies between posted prices and what was charged at the register.
Info Source: Settlement reached in price dispute, Inside Bay Area, December 27, 2007 (via Nexis).

Description: Walgreens agreed to pay $125,000 to resolve allegations by the District Attorneys of Napa, Solano and San Diego counties that it helped promote false advertising claims for a device called the AbEnergizer.
Info Source: Wal-Mart, Walgreens lose AbEnergizer suit, UPI, March 30, 2005 (via Nexis).
WALGREENS PAYS $140,000 TO SETTLE ALLEGATIONS UNDER THE FALSE CLAIMS ACT, US Fed News, July 27, 2011 (via Nexis).
WALGREENS SETTLES FEDERAL AND STATE HEALTH CARE BILLING COMPLAINT, US Fed News, March 15, 2012 (via Nexis).

Description: cashier seating case
Walgreen agreed to pay $7.5 million to the district attorneys of Alameda County and Santa Clara County to settle a case involving the employment of an unlicensed pharmacist.

Description: Walgreens agreed to pay $2.8 million in civil penalties, $300,000 for Supplemental Environmental Projects, and $400,000 in costs in settlement of allegations by the Attorneys Offices of Monterey, Alameda, Riverside, San Joaquin, Solano, and Yolo Counties, and of Los Angeles City, that it unlawfully disposed of hazardous waste in municipal landfills not authorized to accept it, and that it failed to properly destroy customer records containing confidential information.
